Title: Dorsolateral prefrontal cortex: comparative cytoarchitectonic analysis in the human and the macaque brain and corticocortical connection patterns
Abstract: "The cytoarchitecture of the human and the macaque monkey dorsolateral prefrontal cortex has been examined in a strictly comparative manner in order to resolve major discrepancies between the available segmentations of this cortical region in the human and the monkey brain. In addition, the connections of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortical areas were re-examined in the monkey. The present analysis showed that only a restricted portion of what had previously been labelled as area 46 in the monkey has the same characteristics as area 46 of the human brain; the remaining part of this monkey region has the characteristics of a portion of the middle frontal gyrus in the human brain that had previously been included as part of area 9. We have labelled this cortical area as 9/46 in both species. These two areas (i.e. 46 and 9/46), which constitute the lower half of the mid-dorsolateral frontal cortex, have a well-developed granular layer IV, and can easily be distinguished from area 9, on the upper part of the mid-dorsolateral region, which does not have a well-developed granular layer IV. Area 9 has the same basic pattern of connections as areas 46 and 9/46, but, unlike the latter areas, it does not receive input from the lateral parietal cortex. Caudal to area 9, on the dorsomedial portion of the frontal cortex, there is a distinct strip of cortex (area 8B) which, unlike area 9, receives significant input from the prestriate cortex and the medial parietal cortex. The present results provide a basis for a closer integration of findings from functional neuroimaging studies in human subjects with experimental work in the monkey."

@BrainMaps.Comments:
p. 1020: "When referring to cytoarchitectonic subdivisions of the parietal and the temporal cortex, the nomenclature of Seltzer & Pandya (1978), Pandya & Sanides (1973) and Pandya & Seltzer (1982) will be used. For the prefrontal cortex, the segmentation presented above will be used." 
Note: SP73 describe areas of the superior temporal gyrus, SP78 those of the superior temporal sulcus, and PS82 those of the parietal cortex.

For the prefrontal cortex, the segmentation presented above will be used." Note: SP73 describe areas of the superior temporal gyrus, SP78 those of the superior temporal sulcus, and PS82 those of the parietal cortex.

For the description of label, PP99 refer to an area 19 without explicitly stating what map it is taken from. As 19 commonly is defined according to Brodmann (1905, 1909), and B05 is referred to during the article of PP99, we assume that 19 is meant to be Brodmann's 19.
"The present limits of area 8A agree with those of Walker (1940)..." (p. 1028)

"Area 8B in the monkey was originally identified by Walker (1940) (Fig. 2A)...In the present re-examination of the architecture of the frontal lobe of the monkey, we have identified an area interposed between area 9 and the dorsal part of area 6 and, following Walker (1940), we designated it as area 8B (Fig. 3B)." (p. 1017)
"...injections of FB were placed in lateral 8B as defined by Walker (1940) (Fig. 2A) and the present segmentation (Fig. 3B)."

"Area 9, as delimited by Walker (1940), has the following characteristics...The architectonic characteristics of Walker's area 9 in the monkey resemble those of the portion of Brodmann's area 9that lies on the superior frontal gyrus in the human brain...Note that only this part of the human frontal cortex is referred to as area 9 in the current segmentation...In this way, the designations 9...refer to similar areas in both species."
As area FST is not explicitly defined by PP99, we assume that is equivalent to area FST of a standard parcellation scheme of visual cortex, i.e. that of Felleman & Van Essen 1991.
As area TEO is not explicitly defined by PP99, we assume that is equivalent to area TEO of a standard parcellation scheme, i.e. that of Bonin & Bailey (1947).

For the description of label, PP99 refer to an area TF without explicitly stating what map it is taken from. As TF commonly is defined according to Bonin & Bailey (1947), we assume that this is the case here as well.

For the description of label, PP99 refer to an area TH without explicitly stating what map it is taken from. As TH commonly is defined according to Bonin & Bailey (1947), we assume that this is the case here as well.
As area V4 is not explicitly defined by PP99, we assume that is equivalent to area V4 of a standard parcellation scheme of visual cortex, i.e. that of Felleman & Van Essen (1991).
For the description of label, PP99 refer to an area 23 without explicitly stating what map it is taken from. We thus assume that it refers to the standard parellation scheme of Brodmann (1905).
"On the basis of minor architectonic differences, we distinguish between two subdivisions of 9/46, namely 9/46d, for the dorsal part, and 9/46v, for the ventral part."
"On the basis of minor architectonic differences, we distinguish between two subdivisions of 9/46, namely 9/46d, for the dorsal part, and 9/46v, for the ventral part."

@InterMapRelations.Comments: PP99 refer to areas 24a, 24b, and 24c throughout the text, whereas their Fig 3 only shows one large area 24.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "We identify two subdivisions of area 8A: 8Ad (dorsal) and 8Av (ventral) (Fig. 3B)."

"On the basis of minor architectonic differences...we distinguish between two subdivisions of 9/46 in the monkey, namely 9/46d, for the dorsal part, and 9/46v, for the ventral part."

"...area 46 in the monkey, as defined by Walker (1940), is not homogeneous...Only the cortex of in the banks of the principal sulcus and the cortex surrounding the rostral part of this sulcus has cytoarchitectonic characteristics that resemble those of human area 46. We therefore restrict the use of the designation 'area 46' in the monkey to this cortex (Fig. 3B)." (p. 1020)

"In the current comparative architectonic analysis, we observed that, in the monkey, only a limited part of the large region that Walker labelled as area 46 has features similar to those of area 46 of the human brain...We have therefore restricted the designation 'area 46' to this cortical region of the monkey..." (p. 1031)

"...the cortex that lies just above and below the caudal part of the sulcus principalis (and which Walker included in area 46)...We have therefore designated this area as 9/46 in...the monkey (Fig. 3B)..."

For the description of label, PP99 refer to an area 24a without explicitly stating what map it is taken from. As 24a is commonly defined according to Vogt et al. (1987) and Pandya is a co-author of both articles, we assume that PP99-24a is identical to VPR87-24a.

"We refer to this area as 9/46 in both species in order to acknowledge...that in the classical maps of the human brain...it had been referred to as area 9, whereas in the maps of monkey brain it was part of area 46 (Walker 1940)."

"The cortex that lies on the lips of the caudal portion of the sulcus principalis and the immediately adjacent cortex (which Walker included as part of area 46)...we have elected to designate this part of the mid-dorsolateral frontal cortex...as area '9/46'..." (pp. 1031, 1033)
"Other investigators, however, considered the dorsal extension of area 8, which Walker designated as area 8B, to be part of area 9 (Brodmann 1905...)." (p. 1034)

"In Brodmann's (1905) map of the monkey brain...area 9 occupies a significant portion of the lateral frontal cortex, extending rostrally from area 8...Walker (1940) designated a large portion of the region labelled as area 9 by Brodmann...as area 46, limiting the designation 'area 9' to only the dorsal part of this region (Fig. 2A)."

For the description of label, PP99 refer to an area 6DR without explicitly stating what map it is taken from. One common parcellation scheme which defines an area 6DR is that of Barbas & Pandya. (1987). As Pandya also is a co-author of both articles, we assume that PP99-6DR is identical to BP87-6DR.

publication.title: Dorsolateral prefrontal cortex: comparative cytoarchitectonic analysis in the human and the macaque brain and corticocortical connection patterns
publication.abstract: "The cytoarchitecture of the human and the macaque monkey dorsolateral prefrontal cortex has been examined in a strictly comparative manner in order to resolve major discrepancies between the available segmentations of this cortical region in the human and the monkey brain. In addition, the connections of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortical areas were re-examined in the monkey. The present analysis showed that only a restricted portion of what had previously been labelled as area 46 in the monkey has the same characteristics as area 46 of the human brain; the remaining part of this monkey region has the characteristics of a portion of the middle frontal gyrus in the human brain that had previously been included as part of area 9. We have labelled this cortical area as 9/46 in both species. These two areas (i.e. 46 and 9/46), which constitute the lower half of the mid-dorsolateral frontal cortex, have a well-developed granular layer IV, and can easily be distinguished from area 9, on the upper part of the mid-dorsolateral region, which does not have a well-developed granular layer IV. Area 9 has the same basic pattern of connections as areas 46 and 9/46, but, unlike the latter areas, it does not receive input from the lateral parietal cortex. Caudal to area 9, on the dorsomedial portion of the frontal cortex, there is a distinct strip of cortex (area 8B) which, unlike area 9, receives significant input from the prestriate cortex and the medial parietal cortex. The present results provide a basis for a closer integration of findings from functional neuroimaging studies in human subjects with experimental work in the monkey."
